fields.description:
Currently the flow for variable substition is:
1. Create Command Line Object
2. Substitute Variables
3. Recreate Command Line (kinda)

Unfortunately by creating the command line object first we lose important information required for doing the variable substitution (specifically quotes get split out).

It would be better if the builder itself did not create the command line object but just provided e.g the extecutable and the args (as strings).  Which could get substituted and then processed into a command line.

This will change interfaces plugins deal with so should be backwards compatible and documented...
fields.summary: Improve command interface to allow better variable substitution

fields.description:
There are a number of flaws with the way build expiry works currently and can cause pain on larger instances. (http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-3949).

Some improvements that could occur include:
1. Reducing the scope of each session that is held (less stale data)
2. Ensuring that changes are persisted as soon as possible
3. Improve general performance to reduce the amount of time that the data is kept for. 
4. Anyway we can reduce the amount of data stored in memory in general

... there are many others, these are the ones that would help allleviate situations as seen in the JIRA linked above.
fields.summary: Improve Build Expiry Performance

fields.description:
There is currently the opportunity for race conditions to occur when updating build results.  Builds read from session can sit a while before being saved and when saved will overwrite any changes that occurred in the mean time.

See http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-3949 for a nice example of the problems it can cause...

The idea behind this task is to move all core operations that occur on a build to the build manager/dao to be performed in a similar way to the way we increment the next build number (i.e safer).
Key candidates for moving include:
* Setting first and last build number
* The suspended from building (maybe)
* I would also check the vcs revision key, for concurrency issues, though it already gets updated within the build manager.

We have implemented dynamic updates to reduce the probability that these problems can occur and the build does not actually get updated that often so the risks are quite low, however it still should get looked at.
fields.summary: Improve Concurrency of Build Update Operations

fields.description:
Bamboo agents build to the revision that was latest _at the time the build entered_ the queue.
If the build festers in the queue for a while and more commits are made then the agent should build to the revision _at the time the build was taken_ from the queue. 


Eventually bamboo will run a build with the latest revision because it will detect the more recent changes.

However users should have an option to choose 'Checkout to latest regardless' and force the agent to update to the latest revision.
fields.summary: Bamboo SVN should have 'force checkout to latest' option to build to latest revision when build is picked _from_ the queue

fields.description:
CI is really only useful if each time a build fails, you can be certain to some degree (preferably a minute degree) that a developer actually broke the build. 
In the real world however, and especially in complex CI environments such as BEAC, there is always a certain percentage of builds which FAIL due to environmental issues.
Measuring and understanding the reasons for these failures is the first step to fixing them.
Bamboo could actually measure and track this.

It could:
 * allow a build to be triggered by both CRON and an SCM trigger
 * whenever a build gets triggered by CRON, it's telemetry gets labeled/flagged differently to a build triggered by an SCM update
 * both sets of telemetry could be displayed separately - the CRON set of data would should a user their 'background hum' it the % of builds that pass if no changes are made.
fields.summary: Allow bamboo to measure build repeatability (and chart 'CI Background Hum')

fields.description:
h3. Case A

Consider a series of builds:

BUILD-1  Test X passed
BUILD-2  Test X failed
BUILD-3  Build failure, no test results
BUILD-4  Test X failed
BUILD-5  Test X failed

In the results of BUILD-4 and BUILD-5, Bamboo reports that test X has been failing since BUILD-4.  From this, developers incorrectly infer that the test passed in BUILD-3 and the change that caused this failure was introduced in BUILD-4.  In this case, it would be better to report that the test has been failing since BUILD-2.

h3. Case B

There's another interesting case that needs to be considered:

BUILD-6  Test X passed
BUILD-7  Build failure, no test results
BUILD-8  Build failure, no test results
BUILD-9  Test X failed

Here, the failure of test X could have been introduced in BUILD-7, BUILD-8 or BUILD-9.  In this case, perhaps it's best to report that Test X has been failing since BUILD-7?
fields.summary: "Test failing since" doesn't properly consider builds without test results

fields.description:
When bamboo detected a change (CHANGE-A) for a build plan from Subversion, it has the "Quiet Period" capability to wait for more changes in order to build for a batch of changes. However, from our observation, we found the changes (CHANGE-B and CHANGE-C) detected during the quiet period is not made into the "Code Change" list after the build (BUILD-1) is finished successfully. The list only contain the change (CHANGE-A) that "triggered" the build.

Even worse, the changes (CHANGE-B) and (CHANGE-C) triggered a new build (BUILD-2), which is an unexpected trigger since (CHANGE-B) and (CHANGE-C) were already included in (BUILD-1). This behavior produce incredible result since it triggers a chain of dependency builds, thus occupying the build agent, which should spend the time processing other build plans.

I can reproduce this problem consistently in Bamboo 2.1.5 using Subversion repository.

I also attached the screenshot of the Source Repository configuration which includes the Quiet Period settings.

Please kindly advise if there 's anything configured improperly.

Also, what happens for the code changes detected during queue time before the build start checking out code for "Force Clean Build". Would the changes be included in the "Code Change" list?

Thanks.

fields.description:
If something (for example a Bamboo plugin) declares a dependency on bamboo-web 2.3-SNAPSHOT, Bamboo web will bring in conflicting versions of slf4j components:

{noformat}
 \- com.atlassian.bamboo:atlassian-bamboo-web:jar:2.3-SNAPSHOT:compile
    +- com.atlassian.bamboo:atlassian-bamboo-core:jar:2.3-SNAPSHOT:compile
    |  \- com.atlassian.bamboo:atlassian-bamboo-api:jar:2.3-SNAPSHOT:compile
    |     +- org.slf4j:slf4j-log4j12:jar:1.5.6:compile
    |     \- org.slf4j:jcl-over-slf4j:jar:1.5.6:compile
    \- com.atlassian.profiling:atlassian-profiling:jar:1.8:compile
       \- org.slf4j:slf4j-api:jar:1.4.3:compile
{noformat}

As you can see, 1.4.3 API is imported while the implementation is 1.5.6.  This causes the following error when trying to run jwebunit tests:

{noformat}
java.lang.IllegalAccessError: tried to access field org.slf4j.impl.StaticLoggerBinder.SINGLETON from class org.slf4j.LoggerFactory
	at org.slf4j.LoggerFactory.<clinit>(LoggerFactory.java:60)
	at org.apache.commons.logging.impl.SLF4JLogFactory.getInstance(SLF4JLogFactory.java:155)
{noformat}

and is very strongly warned against by the [slf4j FAQs|http://www.slf4j.org/faq.html#compatibility].

Plugins depending on bamboo web can work around this issue by adding the following to their pom:

{code:xml}
    <dependencyManagement>
        <dependencies>
            <dependency>
                <groupId>org.slf4j</groupId>
                <artifactId>slf4j-api</artifactId>
                <version>1.5.6</version>
            </dependency>
        </dependencies>
    </dependencyManagement>
{code}

But really, this should be resolved at the bamboo web level.
fields.summary: Bamboo web imports conflicting versions of slf4j components

fields.description:
The following was discussed with Chai:

* Spike will include no visible UI changes
* When a child dependency is automatically triggered we will first check that its parents are in the build queue or have changes.
* If there are no changes for the parent build or the parent build is not in the queue then the child build will execute.
* If there are changes for the parent builds or the parent build is in the queue then the trigger for the child build will be canceled.
fields.summary: Bamboo "Smart Dependencies" spike

fields.description:
The "Completed Build Results" screen currently has the following columns:
Status, Build Number, Reason	Completed, Duration, Test Results,Operations

If the name of the Agent used to execute the build was added to this column list, it would be very helpful.  I can see 2 immediate benefits:

1. If there is a problem with a Build Agent, such that builds are failing on 1 agent but succeeding on others, it would be easier to recognize the pattern.
2. Recognizing that it is running slower on some build agents than others is useful.

I'd actually hope that you'd consider adding the "Build Agent" to many screens and also to the reports, but I'm sure that is too ambitious so I'll stick with this smaller scope.
fields.summary: Add "Build Agent" column to Completed Build Results Table

fields.description:
Bamboo's email notifications include all authors who committed for that build.  For example:

    [Bamboo] HedgeHog - Trunk build 19469 has FAILED (5 tests failed, no failures were new). Change made by Tian Li, Andrew Aymeloglu and Jon Kean

Since a failure involving your commit requires immediate attention, many developers have setup email filters to notify them when their name appears in the subject line.



Unfortunately, if lots of people committed at once, Bamboo will not display everyones name, and instead simply say:

    [Bamboo] HedgeHog - Nightly build 464 has FAILED (3 tests failed, 2 failures were new). Change made by 8 authors

Which causes the email to be skipped entirely by these dev's email filter, causing the failure to be ignored by nearly everyone.
All user names do appear inside the email body, but it's quite frequent for dev's to add other names to commit comments, making it unreliable to filter on the email body.



Feature request:
Please add an option to always display all user names in the subject line.
fields.summary: Email notifications should always include all author names

fields.description:
My team is currently using Bamboo, with email being the primary means of notifying team members of build results.

Every time someone manually stops a running build, everyone gets an email stating the build "has FAILED", and that "No failed tests found, a possible compilation error.".

This is the same notification sent out for true build failures.  This makes the notification time consuming, since everyone must log into our bamboo web interface (which is really slow for us...), only to find out it was a benign action.


Feature Request:
It would be great to send out a different email if a build was manually killed.  Preferably in the subject line, or at a minimum in the email body, to indicate the build was manually killed by a user.
fields.summary: Notifications should indicate when a build was manually stopped

Modify HTML view

fields.description:
The new feature "Hanging Build Detection Event" is a good starting point. But as far as I can see it can only notify someone to have a look at the build. 

We use Bamboo to do lots of testing during weekends. There it normally does not help to inform someone as he will react after the weekend. This means that all builds that are sheduled after the hanging build will not run over the weekend. So it would  be very helpfull if  one could configure that a build deteced to hang could be stopped so that the next builds in the queue could start.
fields.summary: Hanging Build Detection should be able to stop a build.

fields.description:
As the Bamboo documentation says,
"For more meaningful display of test names within Bamboo, the word 'test' is stripped out of test case name names if it occurs at the beginning, and capitals and underscores are treated as word separators."
Unfortunately that causes confusion in our setup since test names already are meaningful and some have a leading "test" and some not. We would like to turn this re-formatting of test names off.
fields.summary: Allow to disable test name re-formatting
